One pretends to have been in a fight But has only fallen down Drunk. Letter to Alcohol The subtlest flatterer of them all, Pool of Narcissus - \u2018Echo, Echo, Echo,\u2019 One belches. Moreover you taste nice. Let the hippies keep their hashish, I am faithful to you And to somebody else as well Whose name begins with a C. \n￼One Every so often up against the edge of Something horrible. Must be oneself how Could everything else be so bad?^ So, one is mad. Why are there never any ash-trays? Why can one never find what one is looking for Although there are clutters of objects Pushing themselves into one\u2019s hands - like dirty socks - Searched for two days ago, Now no use. Why can\u2019t they invent a method of shitting That doesn\u2019t leave one feeling unclean? (They are always researching into More elegant childbirth, Tidier abortions.) Porter said once \u2018What sort of a wedding gift Is a red lavatory seat For a man with pile^\u2019 How can one comb one\u2019s hair without a comb/ 170 t4 f \n￼In Bedroom On bed Onfloor \u2022 (f Discontented wife, covered with Dirty sheet, / Cigarettes and matches,\u2019.(moved) Two horrible orange pillows One empty beer-bottle which contained water. Two socks (fairly dearth] Sand (rather dirty). On armchair One empty cigarette-packet One book, open upside-down Several letters and telegrams, One empty match-box One piece o f silver paper, One piece of cheese. 171 s \n￼Recollections of London A brown velvet-textured High crowned sweeping-brimmed Hat Was walking along the road In front o f the traffic, the buses In Oxford Street (in Hell) It was crawling, mole-like, buffeted In front of the wind An elderly lady, very brave Leapt out to rescue from the wheels Then pushed her way back through the shoppers Offering it upside down, As if she were begging An old gentleman, eventually, Reclaimed it, Smiling, Smiling, apologetic.
